revision.text:
{{Infobox oil spill | spill_name = 2018 Balikpapan oil spill | location = [[Balikpapan]], [[East Kalimantan]], [[Indonesia]] | coordinates = {{coord|1|12|52|S|116|47|10|E|}} | image = Sentinel balikpapan oil spill.jpg | caption = Satellite imagery of the spill on 1 April 2018 | spill_date = 31 March 2018 | cause = Burst underwater pipeline | operator = [[Pertamina]] | casualties = 5 killed<ref name="jg">{{cite news|last1=Normala|first1=Adinda|last2=Ganesha|first2=Amal|title=Oil Spill in Balikpapan Takes Toll on Residents, Destroys Wildlife|url=http://jakartaglobe.id/news/oil-spill-balikpapan-takes-toll-residents-destroys-wildlife/|accessdate=7 April 2018|work=Jakarta Globe|date=6 April 2018}}</ref> | volume = | area = {{convert|200|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}}<ref>{{cite news|title=Balikpapan oil spill widening: Ministry|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2018/04/07/balikpapan-oil-spill-widening-ministry.html|accessdate=7 April 2018|work=The Jakarta Post|date=7 April 2018|language=en}}</ref> }} The '''2018 Balikpapan oil spill''' was an oil spill off coast from the city of [[Balikpapan]], [[Indonesia]]. It was caused by a cracked pipeline linked to a [[Pertamina]] refinery in the city.
A blaze which occurred when the oil spill caught on fire had killed five residents who were in the bay, in addition to causing respiratory problems in the city. ==Location== The spilled occurred in [[Balikpapan Bay]], on the coast of which the Pertamina Refinery Unit V is located. [[Balikpapan]], which sits on the bay, is an energy and mining hub on the island and is populated by over 700,000 people.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Chow|first1=Lorraine|title=Deadly Oil Spill Leaves Indonesian Bay 'Like a Gas Station'|url=https://www.ecowatch.com/oil-spill-indonesia-2555846407.html|accessdate=7 April 2018|work=EcoWatch|date=3 April 2018|language=en}}</ref> ==Causes== Initially, Pertamina denied responsibility for the spill for four days, claiming that tests showed the oil originated from marine shipments and that divers sent had not discovered any leakage on their pipelines. Instead, the company claimed that the oil originated from ''MV Ever Judger'', a [[Panama]]-flagged bulk carrier carrying coal to [[Malaysia]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Harvey|first1=Adam|title=Police question coal carrier crew over Borneo oil spill|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-04-03/borneo-oil-spill-sees-police-question-coal-carrier-crew/9614942|accessdate=7 April 2018|work=ABC News|date=3 April 2018|language=en-AU}}</ref><ref name="emergency">{{cite news|last1=Ellis-Petersen|first1=Hannah|title=Emergency declared after oil spill ignites on Indonesian island of Borneo|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/apr/04/emergency-declared-after-oil-spill-ignites-on-indonesian-island-of-borneo|accessdate=7 April 2018|work=The Guardian|date=4 April 2018|language=en}}</ref> However, on 5 April, it admitted responsibility, adding that it discovered that the oil samples were crude oil and not [[marine fuel oil]] after its 10th sample.<ref name="burst">{{cite news|title=Burst undersea pipeline caused oil spill, says Pertamina|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2018/04/04/burst-undersea-pipeline-caused-oil-spill-says-pertamina.html|accessdate=7 April 2018|work=The Jakarta Post|date=4 April 2018|language=en}}</ref>
According to Pertamina on an April 4 statement, a distribution pipeline carrying crude oil from a terminal in Lawe-Lawe, [[North Penajam Paser Regency|North Penajam Paser]] to Balikpapan which was installed in 1998 burst, having been displaced by 120 meters from its original position. The leaked pipeline was located at a depth of 25 meters, with a diameter of 20 inches and a thickness of 12 millimeters.<ref name="tempo"/><ref name="sp">{{cite news|title=Indonesia's Pertamina says Balikpapan refinery unaffected by oil spill|url=https://www.platts.com/latest-news/oil/singapore/indonesias-pertamina-says-balikpapan-refinery-27950853|accessdate=7 April 2018|work=S&P Global Platts|agency=Standard and Poor's}}</ref> Officials claimed that an anchor dropped by of a coal ship flying a Panamianian flag dragged the pipe, although it did not name the ship.<ref name="reuters">{{cite news|last1=Asmarini|first1=Wilda|last2=Munthe|first2=Bernadette Christina|title=Indonesia blames coal ship for oil spill, not state energy firm|url=https://reuters.com/article/us-indonesia-environment-oil/indonesia-blames-coal-ship-for-oil-spill-not-state-energy-firm-idUKKCN1HC1FP|accessdate=7 April 2018|work=Reuters|date=5 April 2018}}</ref> Pertamina denied any negligence in the spill, adding that the pipe had been inspected as recently as December 2017.<ref name="tempo">{{cite news|title=Pertamina Denies Negligence over Oil Spill in Balikpapan|url=https://en.tempo.co/read/news/2018/04/06/056917360/Pertamina-Denies-Negligence-over-Oil-Spill-in-Balikpapan|accessdate=7 April 2018|work=Tempo|date=6 April 2018}}</ref>
==Mitigation== During initial attempts on 31 March, some of the oil spill caught on fire with the blaze reaching as high as {{convert|2|km|mile}}.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Meixler|first1=Eli|title=Indonesia Declares Emergency as Borneo Oil Spill Spreads|url=http://time.com/5227209/indonesia-oil-spill-borneo-emergency/|accessdate=7 April 2018|work=Time|date=4 April 2018|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Tumpahan Minyak di Perairan Balikpapan Terbakar, Ini Kesaksian Warga|url=http://jateng.tribunnews.com/2018/03/31/tumpahan-minyak-di-perairan-balikpapan-terbakar-ini-kesaksian-warga|accessdate=7 April 2018|work=Tribun Jateng|date=31 March 2018|language=id-ID}}</ref> Five people were killed when the oil spill caught on fire.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Warta|first1=Martha|title=Korban Tewas Tumpahan Minyak BBM Warga Balikpapan|url=https://bisnis.tempo.co/read/1075056/korban-tewas-tumpahan-minyak-bbm-warga-balikpapan|accessdate=7 April 2018|work=Tempo|date=31 March 2018|language=id-ID}}</ref> According to a local [[search and rescue]] worker, the flame was sparked in an attempt to clear the spill by burning it.<ref>{{cite news|title=Deadly Indonesia oil spill caused by burst pipe: company|url=https://www.afp.com/en/news/2265/deadly-indonesia-oil-spill-caused-burst-pipe-company-doc-13o6cf1|accessdate=7 April 2018|work=AFP|date=4 April 2018|language=en}}</ref> Director-general of oil and gas Djoko Siswanto stated that they suspected the ship dragging the pipeline had caught on fire, hence igniting the spill.<ref name="jg"/>
According to the [[Ministry of Environment and Forestry (Indonesia)|Ministry of Environment and Forestry]], about 70 cubic meters of spilled oil have been contained by night on 3 April.<ref name="reuters"/>
Environmental organizations and campaigners criticized the Indonesian government for its slow response, with [[Greenpeace]] claiming it had not received any information from the authorities on the fifth day of the spill.<ref name="newsweek">{{cite news|last1=Zhao|first1=Christina|title=Watch: Deadly blazing oil slick engulfs island, threatening lives of hundreds|url=http://www.newsweek.com/video-deadly-blazing-oil-slick-engulfs-island-threatening-lives-hundreds-871371|accessdate=7 April 2018|work=Newsweek|date=4 April 2018|language=en}}</ref>
The city's residents participated in the cleanup, using simple equipment such as buckets to scoop oil from the local beaches.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Utama|first1=Abraham|title=Ekosistem Balikpapan berpotensi rusak, Pertamina enggan bicarakan ganti rugi|url=http://www.bbc.com/indonesia/indonesia-43656134|accessdate=7 April 2018|work=BBC Indonesia|date=6 April 2018|language=id}}</ref> ==Effects== Balikpapan city secretary Sayid MN Fadli described that the bay was "like a gas station".<ref>{{cite news|last1=McKirdy|first1=Euan|title=State of emergency declared over Indonesia oil spill|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/04/04/asia/indonesia-balikpapan-oil-spill-state-of-emergency/index.html|accessdate=7 April 2018|work=CNN|date=5 April 2018}}</ref> The city itself declared a [[state of emergency]], with over 1,000 people reporting nausea and breathing problem due to the smoke caused by a fire on the spill.<ref name="emergency"/> Pertamina released a statement declaring that the operations of its refinery, which processes 260,000 barrels of crude oil daily, is unaffected.<ref name="sp"/>
Head of the [[People's Representative Council]] [[Bambang Soesatyo]] demanded an explanation from the Embassy of China in [[Jakarta]], regarding a theory that the fire on the ''Ever Judger'' resulted in the blaze and hence fatalities.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Malau|first1=Srihandriatmo|title=Ketua DPR Minta Kedubes Tiongkok Jelaskan Soal Kebakaran Kapal MV Ever Judger di Teluk Balikpapan|url=http://www.tribunnews.com/nasional/2018/04/03/ketua-dpr-minta-kedubes-tiongkok-jelaskan-soal-kebakaran-kapal-mv-ever-judger-di-teluk-balikpapan|accessdate=7 April 2018|work=Tribunnews|date=3 April 2018|language=id-ID}}</ref>
On 20 April, Pertamina's Chief Executive Elia Massa Manik was removed from his position. Among other factors, the oil spill incident was quoted as one of the reasons for the dismissal.<ref>{{cite news|title=Pertamina chief executive replaced|url=https://en.antaranews.com/news/115439/pertamina-chief-executive-replaced|accessdate=23 April 2018|work=Antara News|date=20 April 2018|language=en}}</ref> ===Casualties and losses=== Five people were killed when their ship was trapped in the blaze caused by the oil catching on fire.<ref name="jg"/> Two of the bodies were discovered immediately afterwards, with two more being discovered on the third day and the last the following day. The victims had rented a boat to fish around the bay.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Nara|first1=Gusti|title=Korban Tewas Kebakaran di Teluk Balikpapan Berjumlah 5 Orang|url=https://regional.kompas.com/read/2018/04/03/16403521/korban-tewas-kebakaran-di-teluk-balikpapan-berjumlah-5-orang|accessdate=7 April 2018|work=KOMPAS|date=3 April 2018|language=en}}</ref> All victims were residents of the city.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Rochmanudin|title=5 Korban Meninggal Akibat Minyak Tumpah di Balikpapan Ditemukan|url=https://news.idntimes.com/indonesia/rochmanudin-wijaya/5-korban-meninggal-akibat-minyak-tumpah-di-balikpapan-ditemukan-1/full|accessdate=7 April 2018|work=IDN Times|date=3 April 2018|language=id}}</ref>
The MV ''Ever Judger'' was also caught in the blaze, with its inflatable life raft and the rope binding it to the ship igniting.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Maulana|first1=Rivki|title=Kapal MV Ever Judger Terbakar di Perairan Balikpapan, Diamankan KSOP Balikpapan|url=http://industri.bisnis.com/read/20180331/98/778490/kapal-mv-ever-judger-terbakar-di-perairan-balikpapan-diamankan-ksop-balikpapan|accessdate=7 April 2018|work=Bisnis Indonesia|date=31 March 2018|language=id}}</ref> Its crew of 20 Chinese nationals were evacuated with 1 suffering from burns. While the ship, which carried more than 70,000 tons of coal, did not catch on fire fully, ship's port side was severely damaged.<ref name="imm">{{cite news|title=Bulk carrier damaged by oil spill fire in Indonesia|url=https://insurancemarinenews.com/insurance-marine-news/bulk-carrier-damaged-oil-spill-fire-indonesia/|accessdate=7 April 2018|work=Insurance Marine News|date=4 April 2018}}</ref>
Indonesian vice-minister of energy and mineral resources Arcandra Tahar stated that the pipeline damage may cause up to 200,000 barrels per day in lost production.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ihsannudin|title=Minyak Tumpah di Balikpapan, Pertamina Kehilangan 200.000 Barel per Hari|url=https://nasional.kompas.com/read/2018/04/05/21072471/minyak-tumpah-di-balikpapan-pertamina-kehilangan-200000-barel-per-hari|accessdate=7 April 2018|work=KOMPAS|date=5 April 2018|language=id}}</ref> Pertamina stated that the crude oil flow was diverted to a smaller, 16-inch pipe, although it confirmed the loss of some production in the refinery.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Rianto|first1=Surya|title=Imbas Tumpahan Minyak, Pertamina Akui Produksi Kilang Balikpapan Turun|url=http://industri.bisnis.com/read/20180406/44/781216/imbas-tumpahan-minyak-pertamina-akui-produksi-kilang-balikpapan-turun|accessdate=7 April 2018|work=Bisnis Indonesia|date=6 April 2018|language=id}}</ref>
===Environmental damage=== At least 34 hectares of [[mangrove]] swamps were covered in the spill. A dead endangered [[Irrawaddy dolphin]] washed up to the city's beach, seemingly poisoned by the oil spill.<ref name="jg"/> Environmental and oceanographical experts have expressed concerns of long-lasting damages to the oceanic ecosystem including coral reefs and seagrass.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Nurita|first1=Dewi|last2=Wibisono|first2=SG|title=Pertamina Oil Spill May Lead to Possible Ecological Disaster|url=https://en.tempo.co/read/news/2018/04/07/055917386/Pertamina-Oil-Spill-May-Lead-to-Possible-Ecological-Disaster|accessdate=7 April 2018|work=Tempo|date=7 April 2018}}</ref>
Due to the spill, the [[Ministry of Maritime Affairs and Fisheries (Indonesia)|Ministry of Maritime Affairs and Fisheries]] received reports of oil pollution across the country, such as in the [[Bay of Jakarta]] and in [[Bintan]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Ministry investigates impacts of Balikpapan oil spill on sea ecosystem|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2018/04/05/ministry-investigates-impacts-of-balikpapan-oil-spill-on-sea-ecosystem.html|accessdate=7 April 2018|work=The Jakarta Post|date=5 April 2018|language=en}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.comment: /* Flight proposals */ FIRE proposal was in 2013. The 2017 publication repeated the 2013 concept.
revision.text:
[[File:ASRG Labeled Cutaway (English).jpg|thumb|Cutaway diagram of the advanced Stirling radioisotope generator]] The '''advanced Stirling radioisotope generator''' (ASRG) was a [[radionuclide|radioisotope]] power system first developed at NASA's [[Glenn Research Center]]. It uses a [[Stirling cycle|Stirling]] power conversion technology to convert radioactive-decay heat into electricity for use on [[spacecraft]]. The energy conversion process used by an ASRG is about four times more efficient than in previous radioisotope systems to produce a similar amount of power, and allows it to use about one quarter of the [[plutonium-238]] as other similar [[Engine-generator|generators]].
Despite termination of the ASRG flight development contract in 2013, NASA continues a small investment testing by private companies. Flight-ready Stirling-based units are expected by 2028.
==Development== Development was undertaken in 2000 under joint sponsorship by the [[United States Department of Energy]] (DoE), [[Lockheed Martin Space Systems]], and the Stirling Research Laboratory<ref name=lab>{{cite web|url=https://tec.grc.nasa.gov/rps/stirling-research-lab/ | accessdate=2016-08-12 |title= Stirling Research Lab / Thermal Energy Conversion}}</ref> at NASA's [[Glenn Research Center]] (GRC) for potential future [[Space exploration|space missions]].
In 2012, NASA chose a solar-powered mission ([[InSight]]) for [[Discovery Program#Discovery_12_selection|Discovery 12]] interplanetary mission, which would have otherwise needed a radioisotope power system for the planned 2016 launch (which as it happens has been delayed until 2018).
The DOE cancelled the Lockheed contract in late 2013, after the cost had risen to over $260 million, $110 million more than originally expected.<ref>[http://futureplanets.blogspot.com/2013/12/the-asrg-cancellation-in-context.html The ASRG Cancellation in Context] Future Planetary Exploration</ref><ref>[http://www.planetary.org/blogs/casey-dreier/2014/0123-lockheed-closes-out-the-asrg-program-and-ships-hardware-to-nasa-glenn.html Closing out the ASRG program]. Author: Casey Dreier. 23 January 2014.</ref><ref name='support 2015'>[https://ntrs.nasa.gov/search.jsp?R=20150008244 NASA Glenn Research Center Support of the Advanced Stirling Radioisotope Generator Project]. (PDF) Wilson, Scott D. NASA Glenn Research Center. April 1, 2015. Accessed April 8, 2016.</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/20150006753.pdf |format=PDF |title=Testing of the Advanced Stirling Radioisotope Generator Engineering unit at Glenn Research Centre |accessdate=2016-05-20 }}</ref> It was also decided to make use of remaining program hardware in constructing and testing a second engineering unit (for testing and research), which was completed in August 2014 in a close-out phase and shipped to GRC.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/20150004104.pdf |format=PDF |title=Advanced Stirling Radioisotope Generator Engineering Unit 2 (ASRG EU 2) Final Assembly |accessdate=2016-05-20 }}</ref><ref name=spacenews>{{cite web|url=http://spacenews.com/39124lockheed-shrinking-asrg-team-as-closeout-work-begins/|title=Lockheed Shrinking ASRG Team as Closeout Work Begins - SpaceNews.com|author=|date=January 16, 2014|publisher=|access-date=August 31, 2016}}</ref> Testing done in 2015 showed power fluctuations after just 175 hr of operation, becoming more frequent and larger in magnitude.<ref>[https://ntrs.nasa.gov/search.jsp?R=20180002070 Advanced Stirling Radioisotope Generator Engineering Unit 2 Anomaly Investigation]. NASA. Lewandowski, Edward J., Dobbs, Michael W., and Oriti, Salvatore M. Published 30 March 2018. </ref>
NASA also needed more funding for continued plutonium-238 production (which will be used in existing [[MMRTG]]s for long-range probes in the meantime) and decided to use the savings from the ASRG cancellation to do so rather than take funding from science missions.<ref name=spacenews />
Despite termination of the ASRG flight development contract, NASA continues a small investment testing Sterling converter technologies developed by Sunpower Inc. and Infinia Corporation, in addition to the unit supplied by Lockheed and a variable-conductance heat pipe supplied by Advanced Cooling Technologies, Inc.<ref name="lab" /><ref>[https://ntrs.nasa.gov/search.jsp?R=20160004351 Optimized Heat Pipe Backup Cooling System Tested with a Stirling Convertor [sic]]. (PDF) NASA GRC. March 1, 2016.</ref> Flight-ready units based on Stirling technology are not expected until 2028.<ref name='Meeting 2015'>{{cite web|url=https://prod.nais.nasa.gov/eps/eps_data/165279-OTHER-005-001.pdf |format=PDF |title=Stirling Technical Interchange Meeting |accessdate=2016-04-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160420084629/https://prod.nais.nasa.gov/eps/eps_data/165279-OTHER-005-001.pdf |archivedate=2016-04-20 |df= }}</ref>
==Specifications== The higher conversion efficiency of the [[Stirling cycle]] compared with that of [[radioisotope thermoelectric generator]]s (RTGs) used in previous missions ([[Viking program|Viking]], [[Pioneer program|Pioneer]], [[Voyager program|Voyager]], [[Galileo (spacecraft)|Galileo]], [[Ulysses (spacecraft)|Ulysses]], [[Cassini–Huygens|Cassini]], [[New Horizons]], and [[Mars Science Laboratory]]) would have offered an advantage of a fourfold reduction in [[Plutonium(IV) oxide|PuO<sub>2</sub>]] fuel, at half the mass of an RTG. It would have produced 140 watts of electricity using a quarter of the plutonium an RTG or MMRTG needs.<ref name="Plutonium stockpile">{{cite news |last=Leone |first=Dan |url=http://spacenews.com/u-s-plutonium-stockpile-good-for-two-more-nuclear-batteries-after-mars-2020/ |title=U.S. Plutonium Stockpile Good for Two More Nuclear Batteries after Mars 2020 |work=Space News |date=11 March 2015 |accessdate=2015-03-12 }}</ref>
The two finished units had these expected specifications:<ref name="flight units">{{cite news|last=Reckart |first=Timothy A. |url=https://spaceflightsystems.grc.nasa.gov/sspo/asrg/ |title=Advanced Stirling Radioisotope Generator |work=Glenn Research Center |publisher=NASA |date=January 22, 2015 |accessdate=2016-04-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160330212653/https://spaceflightsystems.grc.nasa.gov/SSPO/ASRG/ |archivedate=2016-03-30 |df= }}</ref> *≥14-year lifetime *Nominal power: 130 [[Watt#Electrical and thermal watts|W]] *Mass: {{convert|32|kg|abbr=on}} *System efficiency: ≈ 26% *Total mass of [[plutonium-238]]-dioxide: {{convert|1.2|kg|abbr=on}} *Plutonium housed in two [[General Purpose Heat Source]] (“Pu<sup>238</sup> Bricks”) modules *Dimensions: 76 cm × 46 cm × 39 cm (2.5 ft × 1.5 ft × 1.3 ft)
==Flight proposals== ASRGs can be installed on a wide variety of vehicles, from orbiters, landers and rovers to balloons and planetary boats. A spacecraft proposed to use this generator was the [[TiME (spacecraft)|TiME]] boat-lander mission to [[Titan (moon)|Titan]], the largest moon of the planet [[Saturn]], with a launch intended for January 2015,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spacepolicyonline.com/pages/images/stories/PSDS%20Sat1%20Stofan-TIME.pdf |title=Titan Mare Explorer (TiME): The First Exploration of an Extra-Terrestrial Sea |accessdate=2009-11-03 |last=Stofan |first=Ellen |authorlink=Ellen Stofan |date=25 August 2009 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091024224613/http://www.spacepolicyonline.com/pages/images/stories/PSDS%20Sat1%20Stofan-TIME.pdf| archivedate= 24 October 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>[http://www.spacepolicyonline.com/pages/images/stories/PSDS%20Sat1%20Stofan-TIME.pdf Titan Mare Explorer (TiME)]: The First Exploration of an Extra-Terrestrial Sea</ref> or 2023.<ref>[http://www.lpi.usra.edu/opag/mar2012/presentations/Friday/1_TiME_opag.pdf Titan Mare Explorer: TiME for Titan]. (PDF) Lunar and Planetary Institute (2012).</ref> In February 2009 it was announced that NASA/ESA had given [[Europa Jupiter System Mission]] (EJSM/Laplace) mission priority ahead of the [[Titan Saturn System Mission]] (TSSM), which could have included TiME.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.nasa.gov/topics/solarsystem/features/20090218.html |title=NASA and ESA Prioritize Outer Planet Missions |date=February 18, 2009 |publisher=NASA}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Rincon |first=Paul |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/7897585.stm |title=Jupiter in space agencies' sights |work=BBC News |date=February 18, 2009}}</ref> In August 2012, TiME also lost the 2016 Discovery class competition to the [[InSight]] Mars lander.<ref name=washington>{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/nasa-will-send-robot-drill-to-mars-in-2016/2012/08/20/43bf1980-eaef-11e1-9ddc-340d5efb1e9c_story.html |title=NASA will send robot drill to Mars in 2016 |work=Washington Post |first=Brian |last=Vastag |date=August 20, 2012}}</ref>
The [[HORUS]] mission was proposing to use three ASRGs to power an orbiter for the [[Uranus|Uranian]] system.<ref name=Smith2010>{{cite journal| last=Smith| first=R.M.| author2=Yozwiak, A.W.| author3= Lederer, A.P.|author4= Turtle, E.P.| title=HORUS—Herschel Orbital Reconnaissance of the Uranian System| year=2010 |page=2471| journal=41st Lunar and Planetary Science Conference| bibcode=2010LPI....41.2471S}}</ref> Another Uranus probe concept using the ASRG was [[MUSE (spacecraft)|MUSE]] which has been evaluated as both an ESA L-Class mission and New Frontiers enhanced mission.<ref>[http://www.hou.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2014/pdf/2406.pdf]</ref> The [[Jupiter Europa Orbiter]] mission proposed using four ASRG to power an orbiter in the Jovian system. Another possibility was the [[Mars Geyser Hopper]].
It was proposed in 2013 to fly three ASRG units onbord the [[Flyby of Io with Repeat Encounters|FIRE]] probe to study Jupiter's moon Io for the [[New Frontiers program]] Mission 4.<ref name='FIRE 2017'>[http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0273117717303484 Flyby of Io with Repeat Encounters: A conceptual design for a New Frontiers mission to Io]. Terry-Ann Suer, Sebastiano Padovan, Jennifer L. Whitten, Ross W.K. Potter, Svetlana Shkolyar, Morgan Cable, Catherine Walker, Jamey Szalay, Charles Parker, John Cumbers, Diana Gentry, Tanya Harrison, Shantanu Naidu, Harold J. Trammell, Jason Reimuller, Charles J. Budney, Leslie L. Lowes. ''Advances in Space Research'', Volume 60, Issue 5, 1 September 2017, Pages 1080-1100</ref><ref name='FIRE 2013'>[http://www.lpi.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2013/pdf/2874.pdf Flyby of Io with Repeat Encounters (FIRE): A New Frontiers Mission Designed to Study the Innermost Volcanic Body in the Solar System]. (PDF) R. W. K. Potter, M. L. Cable, J. Cum-bers, D. M. Gentry, T. N. Harrison, S. Naidu, S. Padovan6, C. W. Parker, J. Reimuller, S. Shkolyar, T-A. Su-er, J. R. Szalay, H. J. Trammell, C. C. Walker, J. L. Whitten and C. J. Budney. ''44th Lunar and Planetary Science Conference (2013)''.</ref>
==See also== * [[Nuclear power in space]] * [[Radioisotope heater unit]] * [[Stirling engine]] * [[Stirling radioisotope generator]]

==External links== *[http://esto.nasa.gov/conferences/nstc2007/papers/Shaltens_Richard_D2P1_NSTC-07-0138.pdf Advanced Stirling Technology Development at NASA Glenn Research Center] at NASA, 2015 (PDF) *[https://web.archive.org/web/20160420084629/https://prod.nais.nasa.gov/eps/eps_data/165279-OTHER-005-001.pdf ASRG Technical Interchange Meeting] at NASA, 2015 (PDF) *[https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/20150011443.pdf Advanced Stirling Convertor [sic] Development for NASA Radioisotope Power Systems]. Sunpower, Inc. & GRC. April 1, 2015.

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 1 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9)
revision.text:
[[Image:Steam Generator.png|thumb|right|350px|Schematic diagram of typical coal-fired power plant steam generator highlighting the air preheater (APH) location.]]
An '''air preheater''' (APH) is any device designed to heat [[air]] before another process (for example, [[combustion]] in a [[boiler]]) with the primary objective of increasing the thermal efficiency of the process. They may be used alone or to replace a [[recuperator|recuperative]] heat system or to replace a steam coil.
In particular, this article describes the combustion air preheaters used in large [[boilers]] found in [[thermal power station]]s producing [[electric power]] from e.g. [[fossil fuel power plant|fossil fuels]], [[biomass]] or [[incinerator|waste]].<ref name=Liu>{{cite book|author1=Sadik Kakaç |author2=Hongtan Liu |title=Heat Exchangers: Selection, Rating and Thermal Design|edition=2nd|publisher=CRC Press|year=2002|isbn=0-8493-0902-6}}</ref><ref name=BW>{{cite book|author =Babcock & Wilcox Co.|title=Steam: Its Generation and Use|edition=41st|year=2005|isbn=0-9634570-0-4}}</ref><ref name=Sadik>{{cite book|author =Sadik Kakaç (Editor)|title=Boilers. Evaporators and Condensers|edition= |publisher=Wiley Interscience|date=April 1991|isbn=0-471-62170-6}} (See Chapter 8 by Z.H. Lin)</ref><ref>{{cite book|author =British Electricity International|title=Modern Power Station Practice: incorporating modern power system practice|edition=3rd Edition (12 volume set)|publisher=Pergamon|year=1991|isbn=0-08-040510-X}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author =Thomas C. Elliott |author2=Kao Chen |author3=Robert Swanekamp |title=Standard Handbook of Powerplant Engineering|edition=2nd|publisher=McGraw-Hill Professional|year=1997|isbn=0-07-019435-1}}</ref>
The purpose of the air preheater is to recover the heat from the boiler [[flue gas]] which increases the thermal efficiency of the boiler by reducing the useful heat lost in the flue gas. As a consequence, the flue gases are also conveyed to the [[flue gas stack]] (or [[chimney]]) at a lower temperature, allowing simplified design of the conveyance system and the flue gas stack. It also allows control over the temperature of gases leaving the stack (to meet emissions regulations, for example).It is installed between the economizer and chimney.
==Types== There are two types of air preheaters for use in steam generators in [[thermal power station]]s: One is a tubular type built into the boiler flue gas ducting, and the other is a [[regenerative heat exchanger|regenerative]] air preheater.<ref name=Liu/><ref name=BW/><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.airpreheatercompany.com/Products/Category.aspx?cat=1&subcat=12 |title=Trisector Ljungström Air Preheater |access-date=2007-05-24 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928131420/http://www.airpreheatercompany.com/Products/Category.aspx?cat=1&subcat=12 |archive-date=2007-09-28 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> These may be arranged so the gas flows horizontally or vertically across the axis of rotation.
Another type of air preheater is the ''regenerator'' used in iron or glass manufacture.
===Tubular type===
====Construction features==== Tubular preheaters consist of straight [[cylinder (geometry)|tube]] bundles which pass through the outlet ducting of the boiler and open at each end outside of the ducting. Inside the ducting, the hot furnace gases pass around the preheater tubes, transferring heat from the exhaust gas to the air inside the preheater. Ambient air is forced by a fan through ducting at one end of the preheater tubes and at other end the heated air from inside of the tubes emerges into another set of ducting, which carries it to the boiler furnace for combustion.
====Problems==== The tubular preheater ductings for cold and hot air require more space and structural supports than a rotating preheater design. Further, due to dust-laden abrasive flue gases, the tubes outside the ducting wear out faster on the side facing the gas current. Many advances have been made to eliminate this problem such as the use of ceramic and hardened steel.
Many new [[Fluidized bed combustion|circulating fluidized bed]] (CFB) and [[Fluidized bed combustion|bubbling fluidized bed]] (BFB) steam generators are currently incorporating tubular air heaters offering an advantage with regards to the moving parts of a rotary type.
=====Dew point corrosion===== [[Dew point]] corrosion occurs for a variety of reasons.<ref>[http://cmsinc.us/ Examples of dewpoint corrosion]</ref><ref>[http://cmsinc.us/ More examples of dewpoint corrosion]</ref> The type of fuel used, its sulfur content and moisture content are contributing factors. However, by far the most significant cause of dew point corrosion is the metal temperature of the tubes. If the metal temperature within the tubes drops below the acid saturation temperature, usually at between 190 °F (88 °C)and 230 °F (110 °C), but sometimes at temperatures as high as 260 °F (127 °C), then the risk of dew point corrosion damage becomes considerable.
=== Regenerative air preheaters === There are two types of [[regenerative heat exchanger|regenerative]] air preheaters: the rotating-plate regenerative air preheaters (RAPH) and the stationary-plate regenerative air preheaters (Rothemuhle).<ref name=Liu/><ref name=BW/><ref name=Sadik/><ref>{{cite book|authors =Lawrence Drbak, Patrica Boston, Kalya Westra, and R. Bruce Erickson (Editors)|title=Power Plant Engineering (Black and Veatch)|edition=|publisher=Chapman & Hall|year=1996|isbn=0-412-06401-4}} </ref>
====Rotating-plate regenerative air preheater==== [[File:Rotating Air Preheater.PNG|thumb|325px|right|Typical Rotating-plate Regenerative Air Preheater (Bi-sector type)<ref>[http://yosemite.epa.gov/oaqps/EOGtrain.nsf/fabbfcfe2fc93dac85256afe00483cc4/0747540cee26044285256db900597c4c/$FILE/SI%20428A_1.pdf Course SI:428A] Online publication of the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]]'s Air Pollution Training Institute, known as APTI (Scroll down to page 23 of 28)</ref>]] [[File:Ljungström regenerative heat exchanger.jpg|thumb|325px|Principle function for the [[Fredrik Ljungström]] regenerative preheater.]]
The rotating-plate design (RAPH)<ref name=BW/> consists of a central rotating-plate element installed within a casing that is divided into two (''bi-sector'' type), three (''tri-sector'' type) or four (''quad-sector'' type) sectors containing seals around the element. The seals allow the element to rotate through all the sectors, but keep gas leakage between sectors to a minimum while providing separate gas air and [[flue gas]] paths through each sector.
Tri-sector types are the most common in modern power generation facilities.<ref>[http://bwe.dk/pdf/brochure-01%20APH_06.pdf Air preheaters: Rotating regenerative heat exchangers]{{Dead link|date=October 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> In the tri-sector design, the largest sector (usually spanning about half the cross-section of the casing) is connected to the boiler hot gas outlet. The hot exhaust gas flows over the central element, transferring some of its heat to the element, and is then ducted away for further treatment in [[dust collector]]s and other equipment before being expelled from the [[flue gas stack]]. The second, smaller sector, is fed with ambient air by a [[Centrifugal fan|fan]], which passes over the heated element as it rotates into the sector, and is heated before being carried to the boiler furnace for combustion. The third sector is the smallest one and it heats air which is routed into the [[pulverizer]]s and used to carry the coal-air mixture to coal boiler burners. Thus, the total air heated in the RAPH provides: heating air to remove the moisture from the pulverised coal dust, carrier air for transporting the pulverised coal to the boiler burners and the primary air for combustion.
The [[Rotor (turbine)|rotor]] itself is the medium of [[heat transfer]] in this system, and is usually composed of some form of steel and/or [[ceramic]] structure. It rotates quite slowly (around 1-2 [[revolutions per minute|RPM]]) to allow optimum heat transfer first from the hot exhaust gases to the element, then as it rotates, from the element to the cooler air in the other sectors.
=====Construction features===== In this design the whole air preheater casing is supported on the boiler supporting structure itself with necessary [[expansion joint]]s in the ducting.
The vertical rotor is supported on thrust bearings at the lower end and has an oil bath lubrication, cooled by water circulating in coils inside the oil bath. This arrangement is for cooling the lower end of the shaft, as this end of the vertical rotor is on the hot end of the ducting. The top end of the rotor has a simple roller bearing to hold the shaft in a vertical position.
The rotor is built up on the vertical shaft with radial supports and cages for holding the baskets in position. Radial and circumferential seal plates are also provided to avoid leakages of gases or air between the sectors or between the duct and the casing while in rotation.
For on line cleaning of the deposits from the baskets steam jets are provided such that the blown out dust and ash are collected at the bottom ash hopper of the air preheater. This dust hopper is connected for emptying along with the main dust hoppers of the dust collectors.
The rotor is turned by an air driven motor and gearing, and is required to be started before starting the boiler and also to be kept in rotation for some time after the boiler is stopped, to avoid uneven expansion and contraction resulting in warping or cracking of the rotor. The station air is generally totally dry (dry air is required for the instrumentation), so the air used to drive the rotor is injected with oil to lubricate the air motor.
Safety protected inspection windows are provided for viewing the preheater's internal operation under all operating conditions.
The baskets are in the sector housings provided on the rotor and are renewable. The life of the baskets depend on the ash abrasiveness and corrosiveness of the boiler outlet gases.
=====Problems===== The boiler flue gas contains many dust particles (due to high ash content) not contributing towards combustion, such as silica, which cause abrasive wear of the baskets, and may also contain corrosive gases depending on the composition of the fuel. For example, [[India]]n coals generally result in high levels of [[Fly ash|ash]] and [[silica]] in the flue gas. The wear of the baskets therefore is generally more than other, cleaner-burning fuels.
In this RAPH, the dust laden, corrosive boiler gases have to pass between the elements of air preheater baskets. The elements are made up of zig zag corrugated plates pressed into a steel basket giving sufficient annular space in between for the gas to pass through. These plates are corrugated to give more surface area for the heat to be absorbed and also to give it the rigidity for stacking them into the baskets. Hence frequent replacements are called for and new baskets are always kept ready. In the early days, [[Cor-ten]] steel was being used for the elements. Today due to technological advance many manufacturers may use their own patents. Some manufacturers supply different materials for the use of the elements to lengthen the life of the baskets.
In certain cases the unburnt deposits may occur on the air preheater elements causing it to catch fire during normal operations of the boiler, giving rise to explosions inside the air preheater. Sometimes mild explosions may be detected in the [[control room]] by variations in the inlet and outlet temperatures of the combustion air.
[[Image:Stationary Plate Air Preheater.png|thumb|right|266px|Schematic of typical stationary-plate regenerative air preheater]]
====Stationary-plate regenerative air preheater==== The heating plate elements in this type of regenerative air preheater are also installed in a casing, but the heating plate elements are stationary rather than rotating. Instead the air ducts in the preheater are rotated so as to alternatively expose sections of the heating plate elements to the upflowing cool air.<ref name=Liu/><ref name=BW/><ref name=Sadik/>
As indicated in the adjacent drawing, there are rotating inlet air ducts at the bottom of the stationary plates similar to the rotating outlet air ducts at the top of the stationary plates.
Stationary-plate regenerative air preheaters are also known as Rothemuhle preheaters, manufactured for over 25 years by Balke-Dürr GmbH of [[Ratingen]], [[Germany]].
===Regenerator=== {{main|Regenerative heat exchanger}} A [[regenerative heat exchanger|regenerator]] consists of a brick checkerwork: bricks laid with spaces equivalent to a brick's width between them, so that air can flow relatively easily through the checkerwork. The idea is that as hot exhaust gases flow through the checkerwork, they give up heat to the bricks. The airflow is then reversed, so that the hot bricks heat up the incoming combustion air and fuel. For a glass-melting furnace, a regenerator sits on either side of the furnace, often forming an integral whole. For a [[blast furnace]], the regenerators (commonly called '''Cowper stoves''') sit separate to the furnace. A furnace needs no less than two stoves, but may have three. One of the stoves is 'on gas', receiving hot gases from the furnace top and heating the checkerwork inside, whilst the other is 'on blast', receiving cold air from the blowers, heating it and passing it to the blast furnace.
==See also== *[[Recuperator]] *[[Economiser]] *[[Regenerative heat exchanger]] *[[Thermal wheel]]
==External links== * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X8XpiupM2OM History of the Ljungström Air Preheater]

revision.text:
'''Bioactive glasses''' are a group of surface reactive [[glass-ceramic]] [[biomaterial]]s and include the original bioactive glass, [[bioglass]]. The [[biocompatibility]] and bioactivity of these [[glass]]es has led them to be investigated extensively for use as [[implant (medicine)|implant]] [[Medical device|device]] in the [[human body]] to repair and replace [[disease]]d or damaged [[bone]]s.
== Medical uses == There is tentative evidence that bioactive glass may also be useful in [[osteomyelitis|long bone infections]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Aurégan|first1=JC|last2=Bégué|first2=T|title=Bioactive glass for long bone infection: a systematic review.|journal=Injury|date=December 2015|volume=46 Suppl 8|pages=S3-7|pmid=26747915|doi=10.1016/s0020-1383(15)30048-6}}</ref> Support from [[randomized controlled trials]]; however, is still not available as of 2015.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=van Gestel|first1=NA|last2=Geurts|first2=J|last3=Hulsen|first3=DJ|last4=van Rietbergen|first4=B|last5=Hofmann|first5=S|last6=Arts|first6=JJ|title=Clinical Applications of S53P4 Bioactive Glass in Bone Healing and Osteomyelitic Treatment: A Literature Review.|journal=BioMed Research International|date=2015|volume=2015|pages=684826|pmid=26504821|doi=10.1155/2015/684826|pmc=4609389}}</ref>
== Structure == [[Solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance|Solid state NMR spectroscopy]] has been very useful in elucidating the structure of [[amorphous solids]]. Bioactive glasses have been studied by <sup>29</sup>Si and <sup>31</sup>P solid state [[Magic angle spinning|MAS]] NMR spectroscopy. The chemical shift from MAS NMR is indicative of the type of chemical species present in the glass. The <sup>29</sup>Si MAS NMR spectroscopy showed that Bioglass 45S5 was a Q2 type-structure with a small amount of Q3 ; i.e., [[silicate]] chains with a few crosslinks. The <sup>31</sup>P MAS NMR revealed predominately Q0 species; i.e., PO<sub>4</sub><sup>3−</sup>; subsequent MAS NMR spectroscopy measurements have shown that Si-O-P bonds are below detectable levels <ref>{{cite journal | last = Pedone | first = A |author2=Charpentier T |author3=Malavasi G |author4=Menziani M C | title= New Insights into the Atomic Structure of 45S5 Bioglass by Means of Solid-State NMR Spectroscopy and Accurate First-Principles Simulations | journal = Chem. Mater. | year = 2010| volume = 22 | pages = 5644–5652 | doi = 10.1021/cm102089c | issue = 19 }}</ref>
=== Compositions === There have been many variations on the original composition which was [[Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) approved and termed Bioglass. This composition is known as 45S5. Other compositions are in the list below. *45S5: 45  wt% [[Silicon dioxide|SiO<sub>2</sub>]], 24.5 wt% [[Calcium oxide|CaO]], 24.5 wt% [[Sodium oxide|Na<sub>2</sub>O]] and 6.0  wt% [[Phosphorus pentoxide|P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub>]]. [[Bioglass]] *58S: 60 wt% [[Silicon dioxide|SiO<sub>2</sub>]], 36 wt% [[Calcium oxide|CaO]] and 4 wt% [[Phosphorus pentoxide|P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub>]]. *70S30C: 70 wt% [[Silicon dioxide|SiO<sub>2</sub>]], 30 wt% [[Calcium oxide|CaO]]. *S53P4: 53 wt% [[Silicon dioxide|SiO<sub>2</sub>]], 23 wt% [[Sodium oxide|Na<sub>2</sub>O]], 20 wt% [[Calcium oxide|CaO]] and 4 wt% [[Phosphorus pentoxide|P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub>]]. (S53P4 is the only bacterial growth inhibiting bioactive glass).
== Mechanism of activity == The underlying mechanisms that enable bioactive glasses to act as materials for bone repair have been investigated since the first work of Hench et al. at the [[University of Florida]]. Early attention was paid to changes in the bioactive glass surface. Five inorganic reaction stages are commonly thought to occur when a bioactive glass is immersed in a physiological environment:
1) Ion exchange in which modifier cations (mostly Na<sup>+</sup>) in the glass exchange with [[hydronium]] ions in the external solution.
2) [[Hydrolysis]] in which Si-O-Si bridges are broken, forming Si-OH silanol groups, and the glass network is disrupted.
3) Condensation of silanols in which the disrupted glass network changes its morphology to form a gel-like surface layer, depleted in sodium and calcium ions.
4) Precipitation in which an amorphous calcium phosphate layer is deposited on the gel.
5) Mineralization in which the calcium phosphate layer gradually transforms into crystalline hydroxyapatite, that mimics the mineral phase naturally contained with vertebrate bones.
Later, it was discovered that the morphology of the gel surface layer was a key component in determining the bioactive response. This was supported by studies on bioactive glasses derived from [[sol-gel]] processing. Such glasses could contain significantly higher concentrations of SiO<sub>2</sub> than traditional melt-derived bioactive glasses and still maintain bioactivity (i.e., the ability to form a mineralized hydroxyapatite layer on the surface). The inherent porosity of the sol-gel-derived material was cited as a possible explanation for why bioactivity was retained, and often enhanced with respect to the melt-derived glass.
Subsequent advances in [[DNA microarray]] technology enabled an entirely new perspective on the mechanisms of bioactivity in bioactive glasses. Previously, it was known that a complex interplay existed between bioactive glasses and the molecular biology of the implant host, but the available tools did not provide a sufficient quantity of information to develop a holistic picture. Using DNA microarrays, researchers are now able to identify entire classes of genes that are regulated by the dissolution products of bioactive glasses, resulting in the so-called "genetic theory" of bioactive glasses. The first microarray studies on bioactive glasses demonstrated that genes associated with [[osteoblast]] growth and differentiation, maintenance of [[extracellular matrix]], and promotion of cell-cell and cell-matrix adhesion were up-regulated by conditioned cell culture media containing the dissolution products of bioactive glass.
== History == Larry Hench and colleagues at the [[University of Florida]] first developed these materials in the late 1960s and they have been further developed by his research team at the [[Imperial College London]] and other researchers worldwide.
== Composition ==
=== Bioglass 8625 === Bioglass 8625, also called Schott 8625, is a [[soda-lime glass]] used for encapsulation of [[Implant (medicine)|implanted devices]]. The most common use of Bioglass 8625 is in the housings of [[RFID]] transponders for use in [[Microchip implant (human)|human]] and [[Microchip implant (animal)|animal]] microchip implants. It is patented and manufactured by [[Schott AG]].<ref name="schott">[http://www.schott.com/epackaging/english/glass/transponder.html Transponder Glass]</ref> Bioglass 8625 is also used for some [[piercing]]s.
Bioglass 8625 does not bond to tissue or bone, it is held in place by [[fibrous tissue]] encapsulation. After implantation, a calcium-rich layer forms on the interface between the glass and the tissue. Without additional antimigration coating it is subject to migration in the tissue. The antimigration coating is a material that bonds to both the glass and the tissue. [[Parylene]], usually parylene type C, is often used as such material.<ref>{{cite journal|last2=Poelman|first2=G|last3=De Cooman|first3=M|last4=Puers|first4=R|last5=Willems|first5=G|year=2006|title=Implantation of an RFID-tag into human molars to reduce hard forensic identification labor. Part I: working principle|url=http://www.kuleuven.be/fortand/MFO/articles/06_RFID_01.pdf|journal=Forensic Science International|volume=159 Suppl 1|pages=S33–9|doi=10.1016/j.forsciint.2006.02.029|pmid=16563681|last1=Thevissen|first1=PW}}</ref>
Bioglass 8625 has a significant content of [[iron]], which provides infrared light absorption and allows sealing by a light source, e.g. a [[Neodymium laser|Nd:YAG laser]] or a [[mercury-vapor lamp]].<ref name="schott" /> The content of [[Iron(III) oxide|Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>]] yields high absorption with maximum at 1100 nm, and gives the glass a green tint. The use of infrared radiation instead of flame or contact heating helps preventing contamination of the device.<ref name="schott2">[http://www.schott.com/epackaging/english/download/ep_brochure_2009_engl.pdf SCHOTT Electronic Packaging]</ref>
After implantation, the glass reacts with the environment in two phases, in the span of about two weeks. In the first phase, [[alkali metal]] ions are leached from the glass and replaced with [[Hydron (chemistry)|hydrogen ions]]; small amount of calcium ions also diffuses from the material. During the second phase, the Si-O-Si bonds in the [[silica]] matrix undergo [[hydrolysis]], yielding a gel-like surface layer rich on Si-O-H groups. A calcium phosphate-rich [[Passivation (chemistry)|passivation layer]] gradually forms over the surface of the glass, preventing further leaching.
It is used in microchips for tracking of many kinds of animals, and recently in some human implants. The U.S. [[Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) approved use of Bioglass 8625 in humans in 1994.
=== Bioglass 45S5 === Bioglass 45S5, one of the most important formulations, is composed of SiO<sub>2</sub>, Na<sub>2</sub>O, CaO and P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub>. Professor Larry Hench developed Bioglass at the [[University of Florida]] in the late 1960s. He was challenged by a [[Mobile Army Surgical Hospital|MASH]] army officer to develop a material to help regenerate [[bone]], as many [[Vietnam war]] [[veteran]]s suffered badly from bone damage, such that most of them injured in this way lost their limbs.
The composition was originally selected because of being roughly [[eutectic]].<ref name="chemdent">''[https://books.google.com/books?id=q3oYVzXz8YgC&pg=PA92&dq=bioglass&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=50&as_brr=3&cd=19#v=onepage&q=bioglass&f=false The chemistry of medical and dental materials]'' by John W. Nicholson, p. 92, Royal Society of Chemistry, 2002 {{ISBN|0-85404-572-4}}</ref>
The 45S5 name signifies glass with 45 wt.% of SiO<sub>2</sub> and 5:1 molar ratio of Calcium to Phosphorus. Lower Ca/P ratios do not bond to bone.<ref name="biomat">''[https://books.google.com/books?id=Jp8EyCO8Fw8C&pg=PA27&dq=bioglass&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=50&as_brr=3&cd=7#v=onepage&q=bioglass&f=false Biomaterials and tissue engineering]'' by Donglu Shi p. 27, Springer, 2004 {{ISBN|3-540-22203-0}}</ref>
The key composition features of Bioglass is that it contains less than 60 mol% SiO<sub>2</sub>, high Na<sub>2</sub>O and CaO contents, high CaO/P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub> ratio, which makes Bioglass highly reactive to aqueous medium and bioactive.
High bioactivity is the main advantage of Bioglass, while its disadvantages includes mechanical weakness, low fracture resistance due to [[amorphous]] 2-dimensional glass network. The bending strength of most Bioglass is in the range of 40–60 [[Megapascal|MPa]], which is not enough for load-bearing application. Its [[Young's modulus]] is 30–35 GPa, very close to that of [[cortical bone]], which can be an advantage. Bioglass implants can be used in non-load-bearing applications, for buried implants loaded slightly or compressively. Bioglass can be also used as a bioactive component in [[composite material]]s or as powder. Sometimes, Bioglass can be converted into an artificial cocaine. This has no known side-effects.<ref name="chemdent" />
The first successful surgical use of Bioglass 45S5 was in replacement of [[ossicles]] in [[middle ear]], as a treatment of [[conductive hearing loss]]. The advantage of 45S5 is in no tendency to form fibrous tissue. Other uses are in cones for implantation into the jaw following a [[tooth extraction]]. Composite materials made of Bioglass 45S5 and patient's own bone can be used for bone reconstruction.<ref name="chemdent" />
Bioglass is comparatively soft in comparison to other glasses. It can be [[machined]], preferably with diamond tools, or ground to powder. Bioglass has to be stored in a dry environment, as it readily absorbs moisture and reacts with it.<ref name="biomat" />
Bioglass 45S5 is manufactured by conventional glass-making technology, using platinum or platinum alloy [[crucible]]s to avoid contamination. Contaminants would interfere with the chemical reactivity in organism. [[Annealing (glass)|Annealing]] is a crucial step in forming bulk parts, due to high [[thermal expansion]] of the material.
Heat treatment of Bioglass reduces the volatile alkali metal oxide content and precipitates apatite crystals in the glass matrix. The resulting glass–ceramic material, named Ceravital, has higher mechanical strength and lower bioactivity.<ref name="engmat">''[https://books.google.com/books?id=5iRnJfl7IYsC&pg=SA6-PA21&dq=bioglass&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=50&as_brr=3&cd=23#v=onepage&q=bioglass&f=false Engineering materials for biomedical applications]'' by Swee Hin Teoh, p. 6-21, World Scientific, 2004 {{ISBN|981-256-061-0}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Porous medium]] *[[Ceramic foam]] *[[Nanofoam]] *[[Metal foam]] *[[Osseointegration]]

revision.text:
'''Bottom ash''' is part of the non-[[combustible]] residue of combustion in a [[furnace]] or [[incinerator]]. In an industrial context, it has traditionally referred to [[coal]] combustion and comprises traces of combustibles embedded in forming clinkers and sticking to hot side walls of a coal-burning furnace during its operation. The portion of the [[ash]] that escapes up the [[chimney]] or stack is, however, referred to as ''[[fly ash]]''. The [[Clinker (waste)|clinker]]s fall by themselves into the bottom hopper of a coal-burning furnace and are cooled. The above portion of the ash is referred to as '''''bottom ash''''' too. Additionally, modern municipal waste incinerators try in reducing the production of [[dioxins]] by incinerating at 850 to 950 (degrees Celsius) for at least two seconds forming [[incinerator bottom ash|bottom ash]] as byproduct.
==Process== In a conventional [[water impounded hopper]] (WIH) system, the clinker lumps get crushed to small sizes by clinker grinders mounted under water and fall down into a trough from where a water [[Injectors|ejector]] takes them out to a sump. From there it is pumped out by suitable [[rotary pump]]s to dumping yard far away. In another arrangement a continuous [[link chain]] scrapes out the clinkers from under water and feeds them to clinker grinders outside the bottom ash hopper.
More modern systems adopt a continuous removal philosophy. Essentially, a heavy duty chain conveyor submerged in a water bath below the furnace which quenches hot ash as it falls from the combustion chamber and removes the wet ash continuously up to a de-watering slope before onward discharge into mechanical conveyors or directly to storage silos.
These days bottom ash can be extracted, cooled and conveyed using dry ash technology from various companies. Dry ash handling has many benefits. When left dry the ash can be used to make concrete and other useful materials. There are also several environmental benefits.
Bottom ash may be used as raw alternative material, replacing earth or sand or aggregates, for example in [[road construction]] and in [[cement kiln]]s ([[clinker (cement)|clinker]] production). A noticeable other use is as [[growing medium]] in [[horticulture]] (usually after sieving). In the United Kingdom it is known as furnace bottom ash (FBA), to distinguish it from [[incinerator bottom ash]] (IBA), the non-combustible elements remaining after [[incineration]]. A pioneer use of bottom ash was in the production of concrete blocks used to construct many high-rise flats in [[London]] in the 1960s.
==See also== *[[Fly ash]]
== External links == *[http://www.ecosmart.ca EcoSmart Concrete] : A site dedicated to the use of Fly ash and other supplementary cementing materials in concrete. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20081205075711/http://www.londonwaste.co.uk/index.php LondonWaste]: LondonWaste website where you can see how bottom ash is processed to make aggregate.

revision.text:
{{more footnotes|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox Airliner accident|name=Braniff Airways Flight 250| |image = British Aircraft Corporation BAC 1-11 Series 203AE, Braniff International Airways JP6839068.jpg | image_upright = | alt = |caption = N1553, the aircraft involved, pictured at [[Dallas Love Field]] in July 1966, several weeks prior to the accident
|occurrence_type=Accident |Date=August 6, 1966 | summary = In-flight structural failure |Site=[[Richardson County, Nebraska|Richardson County]], near [[Falls City, Nebraska]] |Coordinates={{coord|40|10|29.80|N|95|32|20.30|W|type:event|display=inline,title}} |Fatalities=42| |Aircraft Type=[[BAC One-Eleven|BAC 1-11]]-203AE |Operator=[[Braniff International Airways|Braniff Airways]] |Tail Number=N1553 |origin = [[Louis Armstrong New Orleans International Airport|New Orleans International Airport]] |stopover0 = [[Shreveport Regional Airport]] |stopover1 = [[Fort Smith Regional Airport]] |stopover2 = [[Tulsa International Airport]] |stopover3 = [[Charles B. Wheeler Downtown Airport|Kansas City Municipal Airport]] |stopover4 = [[Eppley Airfield]] |destination = [[Minneapolis–Saint Paul International Airport]] |Passengers=38 |Crew=4 |Survivors = 0 }}
'''Braniff Airways Flight 250''' crashed near [[Falls City, Nebraska]], on August 6, 1966, en route to [[Omaha, Nebraska|Omaha]] from [[Kansas City, Missouri]].<ref name=fjcifc>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=xjdWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=r-gDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6419%2C2283879 |newspaper=Spokesman-Review |agency=Associated Press |title=Flaming jet crashes kiiling all 42 aboard |date=August 8, 1966|page=1}}</ref> Thirty-eight passengers and four crew members were killed in the crash, which occurred in a farm field late on a Saturday night.<ref name=pckftw>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=PotRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=tRAEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5969%2C1097983 |newspaper=Milwaukee Sentinel |agency=Associated Press |title=Plane crash kills 42 |date=August 8, 1966 |page=1, part 1}}</ref><ref name=csincr>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=dtsjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=1ycEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5040%2C3672731 |newspaper=Milwaukee Journal |agency=wire services |title=Clues sought in Nebraska crash |date=August 8, 1966 |page=2, part 1}}</ref> In-flight structural failure due to extreme turbulence in an avoidable weather hazard was cited as the cause.<ref name=eraupdf>{{cite web|url=http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR68-AL.pdf |publisher=National Transportation Safety Board |title=Aircraft Accident Report: Braniff Airways, August 6, 1966 |agency=(Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University Library (PDF))|date=April 18, 1968 |accessdate=April 8, 2014}}</ref>
== Overview == The aircraft involved was a [[BAC One-Eleven|BAC 1-11]]-203AE, [[Aircraft registration|registration]] {{Airreg|N|1553|}}; the aircraft was manufactured in December 1965.<ref name=eraupdf/> The cockpit crew consisted of Captain Donald Pauly, 47, and First Officer James Hilliker, 39. Captain Pauly was highly experienced with 20,767 flying hours, 549 of which was in the BAC-1-11. He possessed type ratings in other aircraft including the [[Douglas DC-3|DC-3]], the [[Douglas DC-6|DC-6]], [[DC-7]] and the [[Convair CV-240 family|Convair]] family. First Officer Hilliker was less experienced, with 9,269 flying hours, 685 in the BAC-1-11. According to the NTSB report, he had two type ratings in the BAC-1-11 and the Convair family.
Flight 250 was operated by Braniff between [[New Orleans]] and [[Minneapolis]] with stops in between at [[Shreveport, Louisiana|Shreveport]], [[Fort Smith, Arkansas|Fort Smith]], [[Tulsa, Oklahoma|Tulsa]], Kansas City, and Omaha.<ref name=pckftw/> It departed Kansas City at 22:55 on an [[Instrument flight rules|IFR]] clearance to Omaha at [[Flight level|FL]]200. However, the crew asked if they could remain at {{convert|5000|ft|-1}} because of the weather. The flight remained at {{convert|6000|ft|-1}} until permission was received at 23:06 to descend to 5,000 feet.<ref name=eraupdf/> At 23:08 the crew contacted a company flight that had just departed Omaha. This flight reported moderate to light turbulence. About four minutes later the aircraft entered an [[updraft]] within an area of active [[squall line]] of severe [[thunderstorm]]s. The 1-11 violently accelerated upward and in a left roll. At this time the right [[tailplane]] and the fin failed.<ref name=eraupdf/> The aircraft then pitched nose down and within one or two seconds the right wing failed as well. The plane tumbled down in flames until entering a flat [[spin (flight)|spin]] before impacting the ground. The probable cause was in-flight structural failure caused by extreme turbulence during operation of the aircraft in an area of avoidable hazardous weather.<ref name=eraupdf/>
The crash occurred on a farm about {{convert|7|mi|0}} north-northeast of Falls City, in a [[soybean]] field only {{convert|500|ft|-1}} from a [[farmhouse]].<ref name=pckftw/><ref name=bofscfs>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=HiMhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=1mUEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5086%2C1540730 |newspaper=Herald-Tribune |location=Sarasota, FL |agency=Associated Press |title=Ball of fire seen coming from sky |date=August 8, 1966 |page=1}}</ref>
Braniff regulations prohibited a plane from being dispatched into an area with a solid line of thunderstorms; nonetheless, the company forecast was somewhat inaccurate with respect to the number and intensity of thunderstorms and the intensity of the associated turbulence. Braniff dispatchers were aware that their flight 255 had delayed departing [[Sioux City, Iowa|Sioux City]] for Omaha by one hour to allow the storm to pass Omaha; they also knew that their flight 234 from [[St. Louis, Missouri|St. Louis]] to [[Des Moines, Iowa|Des Moines]] had diverted to Kansas City due to the storm. They did not inform the crew of these events believing they were too far from the route of flight 250 to be relevant. The crew was aware of the severe weather, however, and the first officer suggested that they divert around the activity. The captain instead elected to continue the flight into the edges of the squall line.<ref name=NTSB>{{cite web|last=National Transportation Safety Board|title=Aircraft Accident Report Braniff Flight 250 August 6, 1966|url=http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR68-AL.pdf|accessdate=18 April 2014}}</ref>
Dr. [[Ted Fujita]], a renowned weather researcher and professor of meteorology at the [[University of Chicago]], was hired by [[British Aircraft Corporation]], the manufacturer of the BAC 1-11, to study how the weather affected the jet.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://journalstar.com/news/local/braniff-crash-probe-was-first-to-use-cockpit-voice-recorder/article_2854baa9-0f3e-57b7-948c-ddb96c976335.html|title=Braniff crash probe was first to use cockpit voice recorder|first=Matt |last=Olberding|publisher=|accessdate=31 January 2018}}</ref> Dr. Fujita is recognized as the discoverer of [[downburst]]s and [[microburst]]s and also developed the [[Fujita scale]], which differentiates tornado intensity and links tornado damage with wind speed. Notably, the accident was the first with a U.S.-registered aircraft in which a [[cockpit voice recorder]] was used to aid in the investigation. Just before the breakup, the device recorded Captain Pauly instructing First Officer Hilliker to adjust the engine power settings. He was interrupted mid-sentence by buffeting so severe that no more dialog could be discerned on the recording, which continued even after the wings and tail separated from the aircraft. Since the Flight Data Recorder was destroyed in the crash, the changes in the buffeting sound would later be used to estimate the airplane's changes in speed and altitude during the accident sequence.
At its fortieth anniversary in 2006, a memorial was placed at the crash site.
This crash is covered in detail in the book ''Air Disaster (Vol. 1)'' by [[Macarthur Job]], illustrated by Matthew Tesch. US television drama ''[[Mad Men]]'' referenced this accident briefly in the season 5 episode "[[Signal 30 (Mad Men)|Signal 30]]". In the series, client [[Mohawk Airlines]] also operated the BAC 1-11.
(All times [[Central Standard Time]]. [[Daylight saving time|Daylight time]] was used only in [[Minnesota]] along the flight's route until 1967.)
== See also == * [[List of accidents and incidents involving commercial aircraft]]
== References == {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.ntsb.gov/aviationquery/brief.aspx?ev_id=23859&key=0 NTSB brief of the accident] National Transportation Safety Board <!--* [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR68-AL.pdf Full NTSB report of the accident (PDF)] Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University--> * [http://braniffpages.com/1965/images/N1553bn.jpg BAC 111 N1553] BraniffPages.com * [http://www.pilotfriend.com/disasters/crash/braniff250.htm Braniff 250] Pilotfriend * [https://maps.google.com/maps?f=q&hl=en&q=N40+10+29.8++W95+32+20.3(Braniff+Flight+250+Crash+Location)&ie=UTF8&z=18&ll=40.174944,-95.538972&spn=0.001676,0.005375&t=h&om=1 Satellite image of crash location] Google Maps * Passenger List [http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1966/08/08/page/10/article/list-of-those-on-ill-fated-jet] Chicago Tribune

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2012}} {{more footnotes|date=January 2010}} The '''Cooper–Harper rating scale'''<ref name=":0" /> is a set of criteria used by [[test pilot]]s and [[flight test engineer]]s to evaluate the handling qualities of aircraft during [[flight test]]. The scale ranges from 1 to 10, with 1 indicating the best handling characteristics and 10 the worst. The criteria are evaluative and thus the scale is considered subjective.
==Background==
===Development=== After [[World War II]], the various U.S. military branches sent different models of their operational aircraft to the [[NASA Ames Research Center|Ames Aeronautical Laboratory]] located at the [[Moffett Federal Airfield]] in [[Mountain View, California]] for evaluation of the planes' flight performance and flying qualities. The laboratory was operated by [[NACA]], the predecessor of [[NASA]]. Most of the flights were conducted by George Cooper, Bob Innis, and Fred Drinkwater and took place at the remote test site at the Crows Landing Naval Auxiliary Landing Field in the central valley area east of Moffett Field.
What may be the most important contribution of the flying qualities evaluation programs and experiments conducted on the variable stability aircraft at Ames was George Cooper's standardized system for rating an aircraft's flying qualities. Cooper developed his rating system over several years as a result of the need to quantify the pilot's judgment of an aircraft's handling in a fashion that could be used in the stability and control design process. This came about because of his perception of the value that such a system would have, and because of the encouragement of his colleagues in the United States and England who were familiar with his initial attempts.
Cooper's approach forced a specific definition of the pilot's task and of its performance standards. Furthermore, it accounted for the demands the aircraft placed on the pilot in accomplishing a given task to some specified degree of precision. The Cooper Pilot Opinion Rating Scale was initially published in 1957. After several years of experience gained in its application to many flight and [[Simulation|flight simulator]] experiments, and through its use by the military services and aircraft industry, the scale was modified in collaboration with Robert (Bob) Harper of the [[Cornell Aeronautical Laboratory]] (Now [[Calspan]]) and became the Cooper-Harper Flying Qualities Rating Scale in 1969, a scale which remains the standard for measuring flying qualities.
===Awards=== In recognition of his many contributions to aviation safety, Cooper received the Admiral Luis de Florez Flight Safety Award<ref>{{cite web|url= http://flightsafety.org/aviation-awards/archived-aviation-awards/admiral-luis-de-florez-flight-safety-award|title= Admiral Luis de Florez Flight Safety Award }}</ref> in 1966 and the Richard Hansford Burroughs, Jr. Test Pilot Award in 1971. After he retired, both he and Bob Harper were selected by the [[American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics]] to reprise the Cooper-Harper Rating Scale in the 1984 Wright Brothers Lectureship in Aeronautics.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://history.nasa.gov/SP-3300/ch4.htm|title= NASA history of the scale's development }}</ref>
===Other scales=== While the Cooper–Harper scale remains the only well-established scale for assessing aircraft flying qualities, its unidimensional format lacks diagnostic power and has also been criticised for exhibiting poor reliability. The [[Cranfield Aircraft Handling Qualities Rating Scale]] (CAHQRS), developed at [[Cranfield University]]'s School of Engineering, is a multidimensional evaluative system.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Payne|first=K.H.|author2=D. Harris|title=A psychometric approach to the development of a multidimensional scale to assess aircraft handling qualities|journal=International Journal of Aviation Psychology|year=2000|volume=10|pages=343–362|doi=10.1207/S15327108IJAP1004_3}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Harris|first=D.|author2=J. Gautrey |author3=K. Payne |author4=R. Bailey |title=The Cranfield Aircraft Handling Qualities Rating Scale: a multidimensional approach to the assessment of aircraft handling qualities|journal=The Aeronautical Journal|year=2000|volume=104|pages=191–198}}</ref> It was developed by combining concepts from two previously established scales, the [[NASA-TLX]] workload scale and the Cooper–Harper. A series of validation trials in an engineering flight simulator with a range of control laws showed that the CAHQRS was at least as effective as the Cooper–Harper scale. However, the CAHQRS also demonstrated greater diagnostic ability and reliability than the Cooper–Harper. This new scale's acceptance by the aerospace industry at large, though, remains to be demonstrated.
==Scale== [[File:Cooperharper full.pdf|800px|Cooper Harper Rating Scale]]<ref name=":0">[https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/19690013177.pdf G. Cooper and R. Harper. The use of pilot rating in the evaluation of aircraft handling qualities. Technical Report TN D-5153, NASA, April 1969.]</ref>
It is important to note that a Handling Qualities Rating (HQR) can not be assigned to an aircraft, as in "That aircraft is a HQR 5 aircraft." Any HQR that is assigned requires a well defined, repeatable task, a well trained pilot that is actively engaged in accomplishing that task, and an aircraft.
==See also== * [[Flying qualities]]
==Further reading== * {{cite news |url= http://aviationweek.com/commercial-aviation/pilot-report-variable-stability-navion |title= Pilot Report: Variable Stability Navion |date= Apr 14, 2017 |author= John Croft |work= Aviation Week & Space Technology}}
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Cooper-Harper rating scale}} [[Category:Aerodynamics]]
